title: Patrick Anthony Porteous
text:
Colonel Patrick Anthony Porteous <a href="Victoria%20Cross">VC</a> (1 January 1918 – 9 October 2000) was a <a href="Scotland">Scottish</a> recipient of the <a href="Victoria%20Cross">Victoria Cross</a>, the highest and most prestigious award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to <a href="United%20Kingdom">British</a> and <a href="Commonwealth%20of%20Nations">Commonwealth</a> forces.
Second World War.
Porteous was commissioned in the <a href="Royal%20Regiment%20of%20Artillery">Royal Regiment of Artillery</a> in 1937. On 26 August 1940 he was promoted to <a href="first%20lieutenant">lieutenant</a>. On 19 August 1942, he was 24 years old and a temporary <a href="Major%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">major</a> attached to <a href="No.%204%20Commando">No. 4 Commando</a> when he did the deed for which he was awarded the VC, during the <a href="Dieppe%20Raid">Dieppe Raid</a>. The citation was published in a supplement to the "<a href="London%20Gazette">London Gazette</a>" of 2 October 1942 and read:
Later career.
In spite of severe wounds, Porteous went on to make a full recovery and had a distinguished military career in <a href="Mandatory%20Palestine">Palestine</a>, <a href="Germany">Germany</a> and <a href="Singapore">Singapore</a>. Following the war he was confirmed in the rank of captain, promoted to <a href="major%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">major</a> in 1950, <a href="Lieutenant-Colonel%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">lieutenant colonel</a> on 1 May 1959, and rose to the rank of <a href="colonel%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">colonel</a> before he retired in 1970. He had the honour of being in the leading car at the late <a href="Elizabeth%20Bowes-Lyon">Queen Mother</a>'s 100th Birthday Parade, before his death in October 2000, aged 82.
